awd_titl_txt: Incubator Grant: Partnership to Advance Prediction of Noise Impacts on Arctic Marine Wildlife
awd_abstract_narration:
Navigating the New Arctic (NNA) is one of NSF's 10 Big Ideas. NNA projects address convergence scientific challenges in the rapidly changing Arctic. This Arctic research is needed to inform the economy, security and resilience of the Nation, the larger region and the globe. NNA empowers new research partnerships from local to international scales, diversifies the next generation of Arctic researchers, enhances efforts in formal and informal education, and integrates the co-production of knowledge where appropriate. This award fulfills part of that aim by supporting planning activities with clear potential to develop novel, leading edge research ideas and approaches to address NNA goals. It integrates aspects of the natural environment and social systems, and addresses important societal challenges, builds significant educational opportunities, and engages internationally and with local and Indigenous communities.

Underwater noise caused by human activities poses a threat to marine wildlife and is a significant global environmental concern. However, sources of underwater noise, such as marine shipping and energy production, are vital components of the global economy. In the Arctic, marine mammals, fish, and other wildlife potentially impacted by underwater noise also provide invaluable subsistence, cultural, and community benefits to Arctic residents. Shipping and industrial development are projected to increase substantially in Arctic waters, with differing noise sources and environmental concerns across specific regions creating a growing need to fill gaps in understanding and prediction of noise impacts. Research on impacts of underwater noise is especially limited in Arctic waters where access to animals and habitat are more restricted by the extreme environment. However, local and Inuit residents possess incomparable experience and expertise about ecosystems, animal behavior and seasonal movements, and how to safely access and observe wildlife in the Arctic marine environment. Through this NNA-Incubator Grant, we will develop partnerships for convergent research guided by local and Inuit knowledge, leadership, and expertise in two Arctic regions to answer questions regarding impacts of noise on marine mammals and fish species vital to Arctic social and natural systems.

The goals of this project will be accomplished by leveraging existing long-term passive acoustic monitoring projects in two locations in the Canadian Arctic. Research partnerships and a collaborative framework will be co-developed through connecting the US anchoring institution with a local hunters and trappers organization in Nunavut, the regional Inuit government in Nunatsiavut, and a Canadian-based nongovernmental organization focused on community-based conservation. The project will involve periodic in-person meetings, community engagement with summary follow-up, and a synthesis phase. All outputs will be the result of equal partnership and collaboration between Inuit and project partners from outside the Arctic. Activities at every stage will be carried out through co-mentorship between local, regional, and international collaborators and participants. Along with co-development of noise impacts research and long-term monitoring, specific plans will be developed for dissemination and broader impact activities. Our aim is to ensure that the results of the research are shared in a timely manner with resource managers, decision-makers, community members, and the public. The success of this project will yield the additional benefits of developing a broad local, regional, and international collaborative framework focused on building place-based, community-based research and long-term ecological monitoring applicable to other locations in the Arctic and beyond.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
This NSF Navigating the New Arctic (NNA) Incubator Grant focused on addressing critical gaps in understanding the impacts of underwater noise on Arctic marine wildlife. Through partnerships with Inuit organizations, a U.S. academic institution, and a Canadian environmental non-governmental organization (NGO), the collaborators worked to build a sustainable network of research programs based on year-round acoustic ocean observation. The research plans created collaboratively centered on local and regional management priorities in Nunavut and Nunatsiavut, Canada.

The primary goals of this project were to enhance and expand collaborative, Inuit-led, community-based research addressing underwater noise impacts on Arctic marine wildlife. The effort focused on developing research programs and processes tailored to local and regional resource management priorities. Objectives included defining research priorities, advancing methodologies through local and Inuit expertise, and designing all aspects of the project to address community-defined needs. Additionally, the project expanded to include new communities, establishing a network of sustainable partnerships to guide future research.

This project achieved significant advancements in Arctic research and resource management through equitable partnerships and collaborative innovation. Inuit organizations, a U.S. academic institution, and a Canadian environmental NGO worked together to deepen existing community-based research partnerships, establish new ones, and develop research proposals targeting Inuit-defined priorities.

A key accomplishment was the co-design and deployment of low-noise underwater sound recording equipment, addressing concerns about potential wildlife disturbance while improving sound data quality. Leveraging additional support from non-governmental organization partner, Oceans North, the project established two new long-term recording stations, expanded community-led research partnerships, and hired two full-time Nunavut-based technicians who were trained by the U.S.-based project team to independently maintain these sites. This expanded network now spans four Nunavut communities and the Nunatsiavut region, creating a foundation for Inuit-led, community-based acoustic monitoring programs across the eastern Canadian Arctic.

Collaboration with Arctic cruise ship operators and Canadian regulators resulted in voluntary speed reductions and route adjustments by passenger ships to avoid key hunting zones identified by Inuit partners, mitigating impacts on marine wildlife and subsistence activities. A pioneering noise measurement program developed precise noise signatures for 17 cooperating passenger ships, integrating onboard operational data provided by the ships. A proposal developed collaboratively with the project partners has received funding to enhance and expand this cooperation for noise measurement and management across partnering communities and regions.

Research findings and other project outputs supported partnering Inuit organizations in engagement with Canada's developing Ocean Noise Strategy.  The Nunatsiavut regional effort also provided inputs to Nunatsiavut Government marine spatial planning and marine protected area initiatives. Knowledge exchange was central throughout the project period. Inuit partners presented project activities, outcomes, and future plans at an international Arctic research conference, highlighting the essential role of Inuit-partnered research in ocean observation and leadership on the global issue of ocean noise management.

This project has established a robust foundation for long-term underwater listening to support ecological research and Inuit-led monitoring across a large region of the Canadian Arctic. Community-based infrastructure for ocean acoustic observation is now in place. Strong partnerships with local and regional Inuit organizations at the core of this expanding international research network, providing a model for other Arctic communities. New employment opportunities have been created, with Nunavut and Nunatsiavut residents trained as research technicians. The project's collaborative approach equally integrates scientific innovation from outside the Arctic with local and Inuit expertise and guidance, creating robust research programs positioned to address emerging environmental and resource management challenges in a changing Arctic.
